repo.description: A distributed data integration framework that simplifies common aspects of big data integration such as data ingestion, replication, organization and lifecycle management for both streaming and batch data ecosystems.

title: Move KafkaWrapper to gobblin-kafka-common
body:
### Changes
1. Deprecated `KafkaWrapper` in favor of `GobblinKafkaConsumerClient`. 
2. Introduced a new interface called `GobblinKafkaConsumerClient` which is wrapper on top of kafka-consumer. The interface is mostly ported from `KafkaWrapper` except that all request and response objects are defined in gobblin. `KafkaWrapper` used response objects from kafka-08 client library.
3. Added `Kafka08ConsumerClient` which is mostly code that already existed in `KafkaWrapper.KafkaOldAPI`. I have deprecated `KafkaWrapper.KafkaOldAPI` and copied its code into `Kafka08ConsumerClient`
4. Added `Kafka09ConsumerClient`
5. Added a few `ConsumerRecord` interfaces that wrap a record consumed from Kafka. `ByteArrayBasedKafkaRecord` are used by kafka-08 clients that do not support serialization and deserialization of messages. `DecodeableKafkaRecord` are used by kafka-09/10 which support serialization and deserialization.
6. Some refactor in `KafkaExtractor` to use these new `ConsumerRecords`
7. Moved a many extractors from gobblin-kafka-08 to gobblin-kafka-common

@chavdar can you review?

title: Adding java8 build support; build.gradle clean up
body:
- Adding a property jdkVersion to allow java8 compilation. Module projects can define ext.requiresJavaVersion property to set explicitly a required Java version for that project. Build will fail if the build and the required versions do not match. Example: ext.requiresJavaVersion=JavaVersion.VERSION_1_8
- Added the BuildProperty/BuildProperties abstractions
- Documented existing build properties
- Migrated a bunch of library version dependencies to BuildProperties
- Build files clean-up
- Fixing an old bug where the build will fail if the project was not checked out from git.

@ibuenros @abti can you review?

title: Integrated broker into Gobblin ingestion.
body:
This PR integrates a `SharedResourcesBroker` into gobblin execution, which is available through `WorkUnitState.getTaskBroker()`.

Changes:
* Moved a few classes from `gobblin-utility` to `gobblin-api` because `WorkUnitState` is in api.
* Added instance variable `taskBroker` to `WorkUnitState`, as well as getter. This broker is only guaranteed to be available from within a task. In particular, on deserialization of the `TaskState` on the driver, the task broker is not populated. 
* Fixed a bug in creation of sub scoped brokers, which was using the wrong ancestor brokers for scopes with multiple parents (for multi_task_attempt has as parents both container and job, the creation of a multi_task_attempt scope instance was failing).
* Added the needed brokers to the entire instance, job, task creation of the gobblin framework.
* Added a test to verify that the task broker can be acquired and that it is indeed shared as expected.

title: Kafka streaming
body: This PR creates a simple streaming Kafka consumer. This uses 09 (and later) Consumer api and conforms to the StreamingExtractor and WatermarkStorage interfaces. One follow on needed is that we need to conform to the gobblin kafka way of specifying topics. This can be fixed after we have implemented the KafkaNewApi in KafkaWrapper.

title: Enabling current Gobblin cluster code to run as a standalone cluster
body:
Added various scripts and fixed bugs to enable current Gobblin cluster code to run as a standalone cluster. 

Steps to run Gobblin standalone cluster on your *nix based machines: 

**A. Build** 
1. Checkout the code and build (or use Gobblin distribution after this is released)
2. Build using: ./gradlew clean build 
3. A distribution gz will be built with the name of: gobblin-distribution-0.9.0-*.tar.gz

**B. Zookeeper Setup**
1. Download Zookeeper from: http://www.apache.org/dyn/closer.cgi/zookeeper/ and extract it to say /foo/bar/zk/
2. Run Zookeeper: /foo/bar/zk/bin/zkServer.sh start 
(default endpoint is 2181, which is what is set in Gobblin conf as well, so you need not edit zoo.cfg)
Bonus: You may want to run Exhibitor to observe your Zookeeper (really helpful to see how the job execution is progressing later) 

**C. Gobblin Setup**
1. Extract distribution: gobblin-distribution-0.9.0-*.tar.gz to /foo/bar; it will create a sub directory: /foo/bar/gobblin-dist/ 
2. Create a directory for your job configurations (such as wikipedia.pull) and copy your pull files there, say: /foo/bar/job-conf/ 
3. Edit /foo/bar/gobblin-dist/conf/standalone/application.conf and set gobblin.cluster.job.conf.path to /foor/bar/job-conf/ 
4. Minor hack (pending bug fix): Copy /foo/bar/gobblin-dist/conf/standalone/log4j-cluster.properties to /foo/bar/gobblin-dist/ 
Bonus: Defaults should work fine, but if you prefer you can edit conf files (application.conf and reference.conf within /foo/bar/gobblin-dist/conf/standalone/) to change work dir, etc. 

**D. Run Standalone Cluster**
Within directory: /foo/bar/gobblin-dist/
1. Start master by running: ./bin/gobblin-cluster-master.sh start 
2.1. Start one worker by running: ./bin/gobblin-cluster-worker.sh start
2.2. OR Start multiple workers by running: 
./bin/gobblin-cluster-worker.sh start --workerid 1 
./bin/gobblin-cluster-worker.sh start --workerid 2 
.. and so on
Note: Each instance will get its own log file, such as: master.out, worker.single.out (if no workerid is specified) or worker.1.out, worker.2.out (if workerid is specified), etc.  
3. In the logs you will see your job / task execution details and the job output in respective directories as per your pull file 

**Mini runbook:** 
1. Build fails for random test failure: Try building again, Gobblin suffers from transient test failures which has mostly been resolved but still is work in progress. 
2. Gobblin fails to connect to Zookeeper and you see Connection Refused in the logs: check if Zookeeper is bind on port 2181, if not check Zookeeper conf and logs, and make sure /foo/bar/gobblin-dist/conf/standalone/application.conf has the right zookeeper connection string 
3. Everything seems correct but job was not run: check if you have set the gobblin.cluster.job.conf.path correctly to where your job configuration files reside 
4. You added new pull file / changed existing pull file to job conf directory and it was not picked up: Its expected behavior, the standalone cluster only reads all the pull files at the time of bootup. So, you will have to restart the cluster

title: Tweaks for long-running tasks.
body:
This PR adds the ability for Tasks to run forever. 
The job config needs to specify the following to enable this mode: 
gobblin.task.executionMode=STREAMING

There are no streaming sources or sinks supplied as part of this PR. 
New sources and writers can be written by implementing StreamingExtractor, WatermarkStorage and WatermarkAwareWriter interfaces. 

Examples sources and writers will be provided in a later PR.

title: Fix for compacting partitioned folders
body:
Compaction did not worked for me when I used the following timebased folder pattern:
compaction.timebased.folder.pattern='dt='yyyy-MM-dd/'hr'=HH

I checked the code and the getFolderStructure method and it only replaces a-zA-Z0-9 but not any signs like ', = or - which was in my folder pattern to achieve the following directory pattern: /dt=2017-01-01/hr=12/

I added those characters to the regexp and now it works fine for me.

title: Adding a factory abstraction for file-based job locks
body:
This is part of fixing an issue with using static state in ZookeeperBasedJobLock . This cause hard to find bugs if gobblin runs as continuously running process. This uncovered design issues with job lock instantiation which will be fixed in several commits.

The main issues are:
- Inflexible current implementation of JobLockFactory which has the different implementations hard-coded.
- Lack of per-lock-type factory abstraction. The purpose of such factories will be to keep shared state across locks of the same type. (This is what necessitates ZookeeperBasedJobLock to keep that state as static variables).

The main idea of the new design is to
- Add the above concept of a job lock factory: it can instantiate locks and keep shared state among them
- Add the concept of job lock factory manager. It instantiates and (optionally) configures job lock factories. Factory instance configuration will allow to move some of the properties (e.g. the root directory for file-based locks) from job configs to instance level configs.

The first commit does some refactoring of FileBasedLock to fit the new design. Changes:
- Rename JobLockFactory to LegacyJobLockFactoryManager to free up the name.
- Move shared state out of FileBasedJobLock to FileBasedJobLockFactory which will eventually implement the new factory interface.

@htran1 can you review ?

repo.name: gobblin
repo.description: A distributed data integration framework that simplifies common aspects of big data integration such as data ingestion, replication, organization and lifecycle management for both streaming and batch data ecosystems.

title: Changed shared resource broker scopes to be less restrictive.
body:
This PR changes `ScopeInstance` to make them less restrictive.

* `ScopeInstance` is now an even more generic interface, and the broker only interacts with it using `equals`, `hashCode`, `getType`, and `toString` methods. This allows scopes to store additional metadata, for example a job name and job id, instead of a single generic id.
* `ScopeType` now has a method `rootScope()` that returns the root of the DAG of scope types.
* Brokers with `null` scope are no longer allowed. The top level broker is now at the `rootScope()` level.

The effective changes in code are as follows:
* `ScopeInstanceImpl` becomes `ScopeWrapper` which is used internally to store a `ScopeInstance` and references to its ancestors. A lot of changes are just renaming this.
* Public methods on the broker still return `ScopeInstance`. `SharedResourcesBrokerImpl` additionally has package-private methods to get the wrapped scope.
* Added `SubscopedBrokerBuilder` interface (equivalent to the existing `SharedResourcesBrokerImpl.SubscopedBrokerBuilder`) as the only correct way of creating sub brokers.
* `GobblinScopes` became `GobblinScopeTypes`. Added `GobblinScopeInstance`, `JobScopeInstance`, and `TaskScopeInstance` that will have job and task metadata respectively (as needed).
* Changes in tests are just updates to the slightly different way of creating brokers.
* Added a test for `GobblinScopeInstance`.

title: Hive source watermark fixes
body:
## Bug description ##
`HiveSource` creates workunits even when there are no updates in the input

## Root Cause ##
`PartitionLevelWatermarker` creates dummy workunits that contain a vector of watermarks for every partition of a table. In case of _non-partitioned_ tables,`HiveSource` does not read previous watermarks from this vector. It uses `sourceState.getPreviousWorkUnitStatesByDatasetUrns()`. This causes a table to be processed every alternate execution. See below example

**Run 1**
Previous HighWatermark is read from dummy workunit which is 0 (watermark is null). Hence creates a real workunit with table's modTime as expected high watermark.

**Run 2**
Let's say there were no updates between Run 1 and Run 2
No real workunits are created and only a dummy workunit is created with watermark 0

**Run 3** 
Same as Run 1

## Fix ##
Fix is to disable dummy workunit creation for _non-partitioned_ tables

This PR also removes the usage of hive partition createTime as watermark check. This was a hack to fix a bug in distcp-ng. The current watermaking logic in `HiveSource` does not need this hack.

@abti can you review?

repo.name: gobblin
repo.description: A distributed data integration framework that simplifies common aspects of big data integration such as data ingestion, replication, organization and lifecycle management for both streaming and batch data ecosystems.

title: Basic implementation for Gobblin broker.
body:
This PR has an implementation of a shared resources broker.

Suggested order of review:

1. Small changes to interfaces: Removed `AutoScopedSharedResourceFactory` and integrated its functionality into `SharedResourceFactory`. This simplifies usage a bit. For auto scoping, the broker will use the method `getAutoScope` to determine the scope at which a requested resource should be created. A simple factory will simply return `broker.leafScope()`.

2. `DefaultBrokerCache` stores the shared objects keyed by factory, key, and scope using guava cache. It is thread safe and handles all accesses to the cache.

3. `SharedResourcesBrokerImpl` is the actual implementation of `SharedResourcesBroker`. It uses a backing `DefaultBrokerCache` to get the shared objects. It also has a specific way of creating new brokers.

4. `KeyedScopedConfigViewImpl` is the implementation of `ConfigView` and `ScopedConfigView`. It knows how to access correct keys in a `Config`.

5. The other main classes are fairly straightforward.

6. A bunch of tests for the broker.

title: Fixing an issue in QueryBasedSource with handling tables with $
body:
Fixing an issue in QueryBasedSource with handling tables with $ in the name.

Originally, code kept track of two properties: SOURCE_ENTITY (used to access the source table) and EXTRACT_TABLE_NAME_KEY used as the table name in the extract (for writing to the destination). Often those are the same but they may differ if SOURCE_ENTITY has certain characters like $.

Later commit changed the above behavior, always replacing SOURCE_ENTITY with a sanitized version. This broke access to tables whose names contain blacklisted characters like $.

The current commit fixes that by reverting to the original behavior. It also adds SourceEntity class to encapsulate the mapping between SOURCE_ENTITY and EXTRACT_TABLE_NAME_KEY.

The tests also adds a bunch of unit tests as QueryBasedSource sorely lacks those.

@ibuenros @ydai1124  can you review ?

title: Moving gobblin-azkaban to gobblin-modules/
body:
Changes related to moving gobblin-azkaban to gobblin-modules.

- Bulk move of the gobblin-azkaban/ directory
- Removing azkaban dependencies from gobblin-data-management:
   - Moved all *Job classes to gobblin-azkaban/ preserving namespace
   - The trash class had a couple of methods which depended on azkaban.Props which I moved to TrashCollectorJob . The first method (a constructor) was only used by TrashCollectorJob . I couldn't find any usages of the second method but I moved it anyway. The change breaks backward compatibility for the Trash class but I couldn't find a way around it. This should affect only Azkaban-related usage of Trash outside of TrashCollectorJob .
   - Now gobblin-azkaban depends on gobblin-data-management not vice versa as before
- Made the dependencies of gobblin-distribution on gobblin-azkaban customizable through "flavors" (standard and full) rather than always.


@ibuenros @abti @pcadabam Can you review?

title: Add support for alternate input paths in gobblin-compaction
body:
Currently gobblin-compaction supports inputs from one base directory. `a/b/hourly/2016/12/10/{00..23}`. Sometimes few hours may need to be used from a different location say `c/d/hourly/2016/12/10/{00..23}`. This PR add support to have multiple input directories for a `Dataset`

title: Fix PartitionLevelWatermarkerTest time initialization gap...
body:
…between test and code

There is a transient test failure in: gobblin.data.management.conversion.hive.watermarker.PartitionLevelWatermarkerTest

java.lang.AssertionError: Maps do not have the same size:0 != 3
	at org.testng.Assert.fail(Assert.java:94)
	at org.testng.Assert.assertEquals(Assert.java:803)
	at gobblin.data.management.conversion.hive.watermarker.PartitionLevelWatermarkerTest.testRecentlyModifiedPartitionWatermarks(PartitionLevelWatermarkerTest.java:323)
	at sun.reflect.NativeMethodAccessorImpl.invoke0(Native Method)
	at sun.reflect.NativeMethodAccessorImpl.invoke(NativeMethodAccessorImpl.java:62)
	at sun.reflect.DelegatingMethodAccessorImpl.invoke(DelegatingMethodAccessorImpl.java:43)
	at java.lang.reflect.Method.invoke(Method.java:498)

This seems to be happening because there is a time gap between the initialization of time5DaysAgo in the test and the leastWatermarkToPersistInState in the PartitionLevelWatermarker. Right now the test data is spaced around 100ms, but the time between these two times in ranging from <100 ms, in which case the test succeeds up to ~2000ms, in which case the test fails because all the test watermark times are older than the very recently initialized leastWatermarkToPersistInState.

This fix uses the same time for both the test and the leastWatermarkToPersistInState to help the test succeed consistently.

title: Workaround for inconsistent behavior of MysqlExtractor with tinyint(1)
body:
… columns

See ETL-5244

There is a bug in the MysqlExtractor where tinyint columns are always treated as ints.
There are MySQL jdbc driver setting (tinyInt1isBit=true and transformedBitIsBoolean=false) that
 can cause tinyint(1) columns to be treated as BIT/BOOLEAN columns. The default behavior is to
 treat tinyint(1) as BIT.
 
 Currently, {@link MysqlExtractor#getDataTypeMap()} uses the information_schema to check types.
 That does not do the above conversion. {@link #parseColumnAsString(ResultSet, ResultSetMetaData, int)}
 which does the above type mapping.
 
 On the other hand, SqlServerExtractor treats BIT columns as Booleans. So we can be in a bind
 where sometimes BIT has to be converted to an int (for backwards compatibility in MySQL) and
 sometimes to a Boolean (for SqlServer).

The fix is to add gobblin.source.extractor.extract.jdbc.JdbcExtractor.convertBitToBoolean() which returns true for everything but MySQL.

title: Propagate FinalState from RetryWriter and ThrottleWriter
body:
Writer bytesWritten and recordsWritten metrics are not being propagated through because DataWriters are now wrapped with RetryWriter, and ThrottleWriter depending on the configuration.

The call hierarchy is now RetryWriter -> [ThrottleWriter ->] DataWriter. Since RetryWriter and ThrottleWriter are not implementing the FinalState interface, Fork.getFinalState is skipping the getFinalState invocation to include the Writer Constructs into the state.

This fix implements FinalState in the RetryWriter and ThrottleWriter to address the issue.

title: Gobblin metrics refactoring 2
body:
Follow-up on https://github.com/linkedin/gobblin/pull/1419

A POC for refactoring of gobblin-metrics to decrease external dependencies. No significant code changes:
- Created a new library gobblin-metrics-libs/gobblin-metrics-base which contains the basic APIs/implementations for gobblin-metrics
- Moved some common testing classes to gobblin.metrics.testing
- Created a new library gobblin-modules/gobblin-metrics-influxdb which contains the InfluxDB reporter
- Created a new library gobblin-modules/gobblin-metrics-graphite which contains the Graphite reporter
- Created a new library gobblin-modules/gobblin-metrics-hadoop which contains the Hadoop counters reporter

The previous gobblin-metrics library now depends on all of the above for backwards compatibility reasons. It also contains GobblinMetrics and GobblinMetricsRegistry which have explicit dependency on the different reporters. Removing that dependency will require some code refactoring. The library has been moved to gobblin-metrics-libs/gobblin-metrics to decrease the number of top-level deirectories.

Subsequent steps (other PRs):

- Refactor GobblinMetrics to auto-discover reporters and move it to gobblin-metrics-base. At that point the gobblin-metrics library should be marked as deprecated.
- Refactor gobblin-distribution to have 3 flavors: minimal (pre-defined reporters), standard (e.g. Kafka reporter and Hadoop counters reporter), full (all reporters), custom (user-specified reporters)

- There are job level configs to turn on/off emails

### Bug fixes
- Fixed `JobLauncherExecutionDriver` to get callbacks when legacy launcher is used
